Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Hi,
>	I have forgotten the details of this.
>
>	Is the pruning phase applied to the whole population, or to individuals or 
>species?
>  
>
I originally proposed that the whol epopulation would be placed into 
pruning mode. Ken then suggested that it could be per species, which I 
agreed was a good idea - but when I came to implement I realised that 
this was more complex. This is because if I prune a genome there is a 
good chance it will no longer be compatible with it's current species, 
it will get placed intoa new species that is not in prune mode, 
therefore the original species loose numbers but not actually fall in 
complexity! To prevent this I would have to keep offspring tied to their 
parent species - which is doable I suppose, but it things can start to 
to get complicated. So I applied th Keep It Simple principle and opted 
for a population-wide pruning mode.

>	I ask because I think the latter should be more portable across problem 
>domains.  e.g. if individuals/species can enter and leave pruning 
>individually, then they can subsequently either survive or perish in the 
>population, so, as an extreme case, if you had a problem that pruning 
>_never_ helped then all pruned species would die but have no effect on the 
>outcome, because non-pruned species would always exist to continue the 
>search.  Actually, for that to be completely true, if you use a species, 
>you probably want to take a copy of it and start pruning that; whereas 
>starting/ending pruning an individual would make it a new species?
>  
>
One of the major benefits of pruning though is that it keeps the 
complexity of the population as a whole in check, which keeps the NEAT 
search running at an optimal speed. So if you allowed some species to 
complexify without limit you would loose this benefit. Anway, more 
details on all of this will be in my write up!

Colin
